bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, September 15, 1941

div1.p: Wood is delighted with the material Hench has sent her for her book on Reed. She comments on the differences between the stories of Kissinger and Moran. She is trying to piece together Reed's early career. She is grateful for his offer to review her manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, September 15, 1941

opener.dateline:
1338 19th St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
September 15, 1941

div1.p:
I am, as you can well imagine, simply delighted with the ma-
terial you have sent me, and am also very conscious of your
generosity in making available to me the results of so much
of your own work, which I shall, of course, use in accordance
with your requests. I am ashamed not to have answered your
letters more promptly, but between being very busy and slight-
ly ill, I couldn't quite make it before today. My present
intentions are to make a final spurt to clear up what research
remains, and then scurry up to Cape Cod the beginning of the
month and go into seclusion for a bit at the place of some
friends - whom you, incidentally, may know or know of: Dr.
Sidney Schwab of St. Louis. I always expect, foolishly, that drs know each other.

Have your seen General Truby's memoir yet? It is most inter-
esting, particularly in its account of Reed's actions, remarks,
etc. and for the description of the officer's living quarters
at the hospital and the army map showing the location of all
the hospital buildings.

Mr. Moran, with whom I have had some correspondence, had told
me that the I salute you story was legend, which I was rather
glad to hear because I don't like it - it seems to me to have
a touch of pomposity and theatre about it quite
uncharacteristic of Reed, who was, I gather, a charming and
graceful man not given to fancy gestures. I am still, however,
trying to find the precise circumstances of Moran's and Kissin-
ger's volunteering. General Kean tells me that Mr. Kissinger
is too ill to write letters, so I haven't attempted to commun-
icate with him. Mr. Moran tells me that his and Mr. Kissinger's
recollection of their volunteering are radically at variance,
and that since the story is already current, he is willing to
let it stand, on the theory that it doesn't make much difference.
According to Truby's memoir K was first, thereby greatly cheer-
ing Reed, who was feeling dubious about the Spaniards, and Moran
immediately after. Mr. Moran, however, thinks he was first. He
sent me a very interesting memorandum which I shall send to you
for your files when I have finished, if you would like to have it.

I am trying to determine precisely Reed's various residen-
ces during his childhood through the records of the Virginia
Methodist Conference. It's not particularly important, of course,
where he lived when as a little boy, but rather interesting and
completes the record. So far as I can judge now he must have
lived at Liberty (now Bedford) near Lynchburg, in June 1864, when
the bitterly hated General Hunter - who was himself a Virginian
and who showed the most extraordinary venom and fury in his dep-
radations through the Vally - was chased through there by Jubal
Early with a considerably inferior force. The episode of the
stolen horses the following spring took place in Brunswick
County which must have been uncomfortably close to the theatre
of operations - i.e. the siege of Petersburg. Also I think I've
turned up another unimportant but mildly interesting episode
which took place when he was staioned in Nebraska across the
border from Cheyenne: a book, so I am told, about an extra-
ordinary old ruffian, Old Jules, who was a homesteader in
Wyoming, mentions that he was injured and taken to the nearby
Army post, Camp Sindey Sidney, where he was treated by Dr. Reed.
I haven't checked this yet, but hope it's true - it makes a
good story and is the kind of thing I need.

Carroll's letters were interesting, I thought, for certain spe-
cific details of their movements - for instance, I had wondered
who was with Reed when he and others watched Moran get bitten
by in the infected mosquito building. Poor fellow, he seems to
have felt inferior and touchy, to judge from his satisfaction
that Slocum addressed him as “Carroll.” Also, Agramonte's
account of the experiments and episodes connected with them are
is very good.

I'll see what I can do about getting to look at Mrs. Reed's ms
again - I think I am suffering fully as much from her illness as
she, by now. (I hope that doesn't sound callous - I'm actually
much more sorry for her illness than bothered about my incon-
venience.) As a matter of fact, I'm a little relieved, too,
that you didn't send me your copy, because if I saw it, it would
be hard not to draw on it, and I'd feel uneasy about not having
her permission,- all this aside from the complete folly of jeo-
pardizing your relations with the Reeds, which are so much more
important. I'll ask my published if they'd be interested in
her ms, just in case.

Your offer to go over my ms when it is complete pleases me very
much indeed, and I shall regard it as a great additional kind-
ness if you will. The idea had already crossed my mind, but I
have already imposed on you so much that I would not have sug-
gested it for that reason. I simply can't tell you how keenly
I appreciate your very generous cooperation in all of this.
I'll take the utmost care of your material and not keep it un-
duely long.
